metadata.title: File management | Apple Developer Documentation
metadata.author: Apple Inc.
metadata.summary: Apple Developer Documentation page providing comprehensive guidelines for implementing file management functionality in apps across Apple platforms. The document covers creating and opening files, saving work, Quick Look previews, platform-specific considerations for iOS/iPadOS and macOS, and related resources for developers.
metadata.copyright: Copyright 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

content.text: File management
Some apps can support documents and files that people expect to manage throughout the system.

content.description: A stylized illustration showing a document icon with a folded corner in orange/amber color, positioned above a simplified representation of multiple platform device icons (iOS, iPadOS, macOS, tvOS, visionOS, watchOS) shown as small gray rounded rectangles arranged in a 2x3 grid pattern.
content.composition: Central document icon above platform indicators, clean minimalist design
content.technicalDetails: Vector illustration style consistent with Apple design language
content.contextualRelevance: Visual representation of the file management concept and its cross-platform applicability

content.text: Document-based apps — such as Pages, Keynote, Photos, and Preview — help people create, edit, and save documents and files, often providing customized ways for people to browse for content they want to open in the app.

People also expect to browse documents without first opening a document-based app. On a Mac, for example, people use the Finder to access the macOS file system; on iPhone, iPad, and Apple Vision Pro, people use the Files app to manage the documents and files on their device. In watchOS and tvOS, people don't typically create, edit, or manage documents, so these systems don't provide a document-browsing interface.
Creating and opening files

Use app menus and keyboard shortcuts to give people convenient ways to create and open documents. In iPadOS and macOS, people expect to create new documents or open existing ones using familiar menu commands. When you provide commands like New or Open, iPadOS presents them in the shortcuts interface that displays when people hold the Command key on a connected hardware keyboard, and macOS presents them in the menu bar File menu. Regardless of the availability of keyboard shortcuts, include an Add (+) button to help people create a new document. In a macOS app, you put the add action in the File menu (for guidance, see File menu).

emphasis.text: Use app menus and keyboard shortcuts to give people convenient ways to create and open documents.

content.text: If your app requires a custom file browser, support people's understanding of the platform's file system. People who are familiar with the Finder and Files apps already understand the basic layout of their device's file system. Although you might want to show the most relevant part of the file system when your custom file browser opens — for example, a Documents or iCloud folder or the most recently selected location — let people use your browser to view the rest of the file system if they want.

emphasis.text: If your app requires a custom file browser, support people's understanding of the platform's file system.

content.text: Saving work

Help people be confident that their work is always preserved unless they cancel or delete it. In general, avoid making people take an explicit action to save their work. Instead, automatically perform periodic saves while they're editing and when they close a file or switch to another app.

emphasis.text: Help people be confident that their work is always preserved unless they cancel or delete it.

content.text: Hide file extensions by default, but let people view them if they choose. Be sure to reflect the current choice in all the save or open interfaces you display.

emphasis.text: Hide file extensions by default, but let people view them if they choose.

content.text: Quick Look previews

Quick Look helps you create previews of the files your app handles so that people can view them within your app and in some cases interact with them. For example, you can use Quick Look to let people listen to a preview of an audio file, add markup to a photo's preview, or rotate and scale a 3D file preview to examine it in different ways.

Use a Quick Look viewer to let people preview a file even when your app can't open it. If your app lets people attach or otherwise interact with files that it doesn't support, implementing a Quick Look viewer lets people preview those files without leaving your app.

emphasis.text: Use a Quick Look viewer to let people preview a file even when your app can't open it.

content.text: Consider implementing a Quick Look generator if your app produces custom file types. A Quick Look generator lets other apps — including the Finder, Files, and Spotlight — display previews of your documents, making it easier for people to find them.

emphasis.text: Consider implementing a Quick Look generator if your app produces custom file types.

content.text: Platform considerations
No additional considerations for tvOS, visionOS, or watchOS.
iOS, iPadOS
Document launcher

Starting in iOS 18 and iPadOS 18, document-based apps can use the system's document launcher to give people a consistent, highly graphical way to browse, open, and create files. The document launcher presents a full-screen experience that highlights key elements of your app's theme, while making it easy for people to create new documents. For developer guidance, see DocumentGroupLaunchScene.
The document launcher consists of three main parts:

items: A title card that displays the app title and two app-specific buttons
A background image that appears behind the title card and additional images — called accessories — that can appear around it
A sheet that contains a file browser and optional app-specific controls

content.text: You can customize all three parts of the document launcher. Although the system automatically displays your app name in the title card, you specify the text and functions of the card's primary and secondary buttons. You can also create a custom background image, one or more accessory images to surround the title card, and provide some custom controls that can appear in the file browser's toolbar.

content.description: iPad screenshot showing a document launcher interface. The screen displays a full-screen document launcher with an orange/amber gradient background. In the center is a title card showing 'Writing App' as the app name. Below the title are two buttons: a primary orange button labeled 'Start Writing' and a secondary button 'Choose a Template'. Around the title card are decorative accessory elements that appear to be stylized document or page icons floating at various positions, creating a sense of depth. The accessories appear both in front of and behind the title card. The overall design demonstrates the document launcher's customizable background, title card, and accessory placement capabilities.
content.composition: Centered title card with floating accessories, gradient background filling the screen
content.technicalDetails: iPad in landscape orientation showing iOS 18 document launcher feature
content.contextualRelevance: Visual example demonstrating the document launcher UI components described in the text, showing title card, buttons, background, and accessory placement

content.text: Assign the title card's buttons to your app's most important functions. The primary button typically creates a new document, and the secondary button can provide additional options. For example, the primary button in Numbers is Start Writing and the secondary button is Choose a Template.

emphasis.text: Assign the title card's buttons to your app's most important functions.

content.text: Provide a background that's clearly distinct from the accessories and title card. You can use a solid color, a gradient, or a pattern. Avoid including complex images or patterns that might distract from foreground elements.

emphasis.text: Provide a background that's clearly distinct from the accessories and title card.

content.text: Be mindful of accessory placement. For example, you can place accessories both in front of and behind the title card to create the appearance of depth, but you need to make sure that your app name and both buttons remain clearly visible. Avoid cluttering the title card with too many accessories, and be sure to test its overall appearance across the range of screen sizes and device orientations that you support.

Use animation sparingly. Too much motion on the display can confuse or disorient people. If you want to animate your accessories, consider creating gentle, repeating animations that subtly highlight and enhance your app's content. For example, you might create an animation that makes an accessory appear to breathe or sway softly. For guidance, see Motion.
File provider app extension

If your app can share its files with other apps, you can create a file provider app extension that displays a custom interface for importing, exporting, opening, and moving your app's documents. For developer guidance, see File Provider. An app extension is code you provide that people can install and use to extend the functionality of a specific area of the system; to learn more, see App extensions.

When someone uses your file provider extension to open or import documents, display only documents that are appropriate in the current context. For example, if a PDF-editing app loads your extension, only list PDF files for opening or import. You might also want to display additional information, such as modification dates, sizes, and whether documents are local or remote.

emphasis.text: When someone uses your file provider extension to open or import documents, display only documents that are appropriate in the current context.

content.text: Let people select a destination when exporting and moving documents. Unless your app stores documents in a single directory, let people navigate to a specific destination in your directory hierarchy. You could also provide a way to add new subdirectories.

emphasis.text: Let people select a destination when exporting and moving documents.

content.text: Avoid including a custom top toolbar. Your extension loads within a modal view that already includes a toolbar. Providing a second toolbar is confusing and takes space away from your content.

emphasis.text: Avoid including a custom top toolbar.

content.text: Your app can also let people browse and open files from other apps. For developer guidance, see Adding a document browser to your app.

externalLinks.text: Adding a document browser to your app
externalLinks.destination: Apple Developer Documentation - Adding a document browser to your app

content.text: macOS
Custom file management

People have strong associations with the familiar file browsing experience of the Finder and most document-based apps. Use the default file browser unless you have an important reason to create a custom one.

Make your custom file-opening interface convenient. For example, people might appreciate an "open recent" action in addition to the simple "open" action. You might also want to let people choose criteria on which to filter the file-browsing experience, or select multiple documents to open at once. In a macOS open panel, you can customize the title of the Open button to reflect the task — for example, if your app lets people insert a file's contents into the current document, you might change the title to Insert.

emphasis.text: Make your custom file-opening interface convenient.

content.text: Provide a save interface to let people change a file's name, format, or location. By default, a new document's title is "Untitled" until people choose a custom name. As with a document-opening interface, a save view can also provide a browsing experience that defaults to a logical location to help people place the saved document where they want. If you support saving content in different formats, also give people a way to choose a specific file format.

emphasis.text: Provide a save interface to let people change a file's name, format, or location.

content.text: Consider extending the functionality of the Save dialog. If it makes sense in your app, you can add a custom accessory view containing useful settings or options to the Save dialog. For example, the dialog for saving Mail messages as files contains an option to include attachments.

emphasis.text: Consider extending the functionality of the Save dialog.

content.text: Finder Sync extensions
If your app syncs local and remote files, you can create a Finder Sync app extension to express file synchronization status and control within the Finder. For developer guidance, see Finder Sync.
For example, you can use a Finder Sync extension to:

items: Display badges in the Finder to indicate the sync status of items
Provide custom contextual menu items that perform file and folder management tasks, like favoriting and adding password-protection
Provide custom toolbar buttons that perform global actions, like initiating a sync operation

content.text: Help people avoid losing work if they turn off autosaving. People can turn off autosaving by selecting the "Ask to keep changes when closing documents" toggle in Desktop & Dock settings. In this scenario, show that a document has unsaved changes and present a save dialog when people choose to close the document, quit your app, log out, or restart.

emphasis.text: Help people avoid losing work if they turn off autosaving.

content.text: When autosaving is off, make sure people know when a document has unsaved changes. To show that there are unsaved changes, display a dot on the document window's close button and next to the document's name in your app's Window menu. When autosaving is on, showing a dot in these locations is confusing, because it implies that people need to take action to avoid losing their work. Regardless of autosave status, you can append "Edited" to the document's title in the title bar, but be sure to remove this suffix as soon as autosave occurs or when people explicitly save their work.

emphasis.text: When autosaving is off, make sure people know when a document has unsaved changes.

Related
Developer documentation
Videos
Change log

cells.content: Added guidelines for using the document launcher in iOS and iPadOS.
Updated to include guidance for visionOS.

content.tableSummary: Document revision history showing two updates: June 2024 addition of document launcher guidelines for iOS/iPadOS, and June 2023 addition of visionOS guidance.

content.text: To submit feedback on documentation, visit Feedback Assistant.

pages.pageSummary: Apple Developer Documentation page providing comprehensive Human Interface Guidelines for implementing file management functionality in apps across all Apple platforms. The page covers four main topics: creating and opening files (using menus, keyboard shortcuts, and custom file browsers), saving work (autosaving best practices and file extension handling), Quick Look previews (implementing viewers and generators), and platform-specific considerations. For iOS/iPadOS, it details the new document launcher feature introduced in iOS 18 and file provider app extensions. For macOS, it covers custom file management interfaces and Finder Sync extensions for cloud storage apps. The page includes an illustrative screenshot of the document launcher UI and provides links to related documentation, developer resources, and WWDC videos.

sections.title: Introduction
sections.summary: Overview of document-based apps and file management expectations across Apple platforms, noting that Pages, Keynote, Photos, and Preview are examples, and explaining that watchOS and tvOS do not provide document browsing interfaces.

sections.title: Creating and opening files
sections.summary: Guidelines for providing convenient ways to create and open documents through menus, keyboard shortcuts, and Add buttons. Advises supporting user understanding of the file system when implementing custom file browsers.

sections.title: Saving work
sections.summary: Best practices for autosaving work automatically, preserving user confidence in data persistence, and handling file extensions visibility.

sections.title: Quick Look previews
sections.summary: Guidance on implementing Quick Look viewers to preview files the app cannot open, and Quick Look generators for custom file types to enable system-wide previews.

sections.title: iOS, iPadOS Platform Considerations

subsections.title: Document launcher
subsections.summary: New iOS 18/iPadOS 18 feature providing full-screen document launcher with customizable title card, background, accessories, and file browser. Guidelines cover button assignment, background design, accessory placement, and animation usage.

subsections.title: File provider app extension
subsections.summary: Creating app extensions for sharing files with other apps, including context-appropriate document filtering, destination selection for exports, and avoiding redundant toolbars.

sections.summary: Platform-specific guidance for iOS and iPadOS including the document launcher and file provider extensions.

sections.title: macOS Platform Considerations

subsections.title: Custom file management
subsections.summary: Guidelines for custom file opening interfaces (open recent, filtering, multiple selection), save interfaces (name, format, location), and extending Save dialog functionality.

subsections.title: Finder Sync extensions
subsections.summary: Creating Finder Sync extensions to show sync status badges, provide contextual menu items, and add toolbar buttons for file synchronization apps.

sections.summary: Platform-specific guidance for macOS including custom file management, Finder Sync extensions, and autosave behavior handling.

sections.title: Resources
sections.summary: Links to related HIG topics (Toolbars, File menu, Printing), developer documentation (Documents - SwiftUI), and WWDC videos (Build document-based apps in SwiftUI).

sections.title: Change log
sections.summary: Document revision history showing June 2024 addition of document launcher guidelines and June 2023 addition of visionOS guidance.

semanticStructure.documentFlow: The document begins with a high-level introduction to file management in document-based apps, then progresses through general guidelines applicable to all platforms (creating/opening files, saving, Quick Look). It then provides platform-specific deep dives for iOS/iPadOS (document launcher, file provider extensions) and macOS (custom file management, Finder Sync, autosave handling). The document concludes with related resources and a change log.

keyTerms.definition: Apps that help people create, edit, and save documents and files, such as Pages, Keynote, Photos, and Preview

A system-provided full-screen interface in iOS 18/iPadOS 18 for browsing, opening, and creating files in document-based apps, consisting of a title card, background with accessories, and file browser sheet
Apple technology for creating file previews that can be viewed and interacted with, including audio playback, markup, and 3D rotation
An extension that enables other apps (Finder, Files, Spotlight) to display previews of custom file types
Code that extends system functionality to display custom interface for importing, exporting, opening, and moving an app's documents
A macOS app extension that expresses file synchronization status and control within the Finder, including badges, contextual menus, and toolbar buttons
The central element of the document launcher displaying app name and two customizable buttons
Decorative images surrounding the title card in the document launcher that can create depth and visual interest
Automatic periodic saving of work during editing and when closing files or switching apps, which can be disabled by users in macOS Desktop & Dock settings
SwiftUI API for implementing the document launcher in iOS 18 and iPadOS 18

keyFindings: Document-based apps should provide familiar menu commands (New, Open) that integrate with iPadOS Command key shortcuts and macOS menu bar
Apps should automatically save work periodically and when files are closed or app is switched, avoiding explicit save actions
File extensions should be hidden by default but viewable on user preference
Quick Look viewers enable file preview even for unsupported file types; generators enable system-wide preview of custom types
iOS 18/iPadOS 18 introduces document launcher with customizable title card (app name + 2 buttons), background, accessories, and file browser
Document launcher accessories can be placed in front of and behind title card for depth, but app name and buttons must remain visible
Document launcher animations should be gentle and subtle (breathing, soft swaying) to avoid disorienting users
File provider extensions should filter documents by context and allow destination selection for exports
File provider extensions should not include custom top toolbars as they load within modal views with existing toolbars
macOS custom file browsers should include open recent, filtering, and multiple selection features
macOS Save dialogs can be extended with custom accessory views for additional options
Finder Sync extensions can display sync status badges, contextual menu items, and toolbar buttons
When macOS autosaving is off, unsaved changes should be indicated with a dot on close button and in Window menu
The 'Edited' suffix can be appended to document titles regardless of autosave status, but must be removed when save occurs

designDecisions.decision: Use system file browsers over custom implementations
designDecisions.rationale: People have strong associations with familiar Finder/Files browsing experience
Helps people be confident their work is preserved without explicit action
Cleaner interface while respecting user preference to show them

designDecisions.decision: Use gentle, subtle animations in document launcher
designDecisions.rationale: Too much motion can confuse or disorient people

designDecisions.decision: Clearly distinguish background from accessories and title card
designDecisions.rationale: Maintains visual hierarchy and ensures buttons remain visible

designDecisions.decision: Filter documents by context in file provider extensions
designDecisions.rationale: Shows only appropriate documents for the current operation (e.g., PDFs for PDF editor)

designDecisions.decision: Show unsaved changes indicator only when autosave is off
designDecisions.rationale: Dot indicator when autosave is on implies user needs to take action, which is confusing
